description: Number of divisors of n over the Gaussian integers.
comments: Divisors which are associates are identified (two Gaussian integers z1, z2 are associates if z1 = u * z2 where u is a unit, i.e., one of 1, i, -1, -i).a(A004614(n)) = A000005(n). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Jan 23 2003a(A004613(n)) = A000005(n)^2. - _Benedikt Otten_, May 22 2013
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..10000
Index entries for Gaussian integers and primes
formula: Presumably a(n) = 2 iff n is a rational prime == 3 mod 4 (see A002145). - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jan 07 2003, Feb 23 2007Multiplicative with a(2^e) = 2*e+1, a(p^e) = e+1 if p mod 4=3 and a(p^e) = (e+1)^2 if p mod 4=1. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Jan 23 2003
mathematica: Table[Length[Divisors[n, GaussianIntegers -> True]], {n, 30}] (* _Alonso del Arte_, Jan 25 2011 *)
prog: (Haskell)a062327 n = product $ zipWith f (a027748_row n) (a124010_row n) where   f 2 e                  = 2 * e + 1   f p e | p `mod` 4 == 1 = (e + 1) ^ 2         | otherwise      = e + 1-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 18 2011
author: Reiner Martin (reinermartin(AT)hotmail.com), Jul 12 2001
